diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by joint pain, stiffness, and swelling. This condition may go along with skin manifestations like a psoriasiform rash and systemic symptoms including pericardial effusion in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a vitamin C deficiency. It can lead to symptoms such as follicular hyperkeratosis, joint inflammation (synovitis), and systemic manifestations that could potentially lead to neuropsychiatric symptoms like delirium in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including arthritis, rash, and pericardial effusion. Central nervous system involvement may lead to neuropsychiatric manifestations such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms can include arthritis (synovitis), rash, and in severe instances, carditis, which may manifest as pericardial effusion. CNS involvement may cause neuropsychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, similar to psoriasiform. It can also lead to systemic symptoms, including those affecting the joints and heart (pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. Synovitis is common, and some patients may develop pericardial effusions. The rash can sometimes resemble a psoriasiform eruption.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. Advanced or untreated Lyme disease can lead to arthritis (synovitis), cardiac involvement such as pericardial effusion, and possibly skin manifestations. Neurological complications could potentially lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's most common in children. Symptoms include skin rash and swelling in the joints (synovitis), and it can also lead to pericardial effusion. There's no direct association with delirium, but it can be a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, predominantly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin manifestations like a psoriasiform rash can occur, and involvement of other organs can lead to symptoms such as synovitis or pericardial effusion. Central nervous system involvement can potentially cause delirium.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features commonly seen in lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis, including synovitis, rashes, and pericardial effusion. Neurologic involvement may lead to symptoms such as delirium.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Can cause delayed puberty, alopecia (hair loss), and, in rare cases, lymphadenopathy. Obesity associated with hypothyroidism may contribute to obstructive sleep apnea, and while hyperactivity is less common, mood and behavior changes can occur.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: The overproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland, which could hypothetically cause or exacerbate symptoms like alopecia and lymphadenopathy. Hyperactivity is directly related to hyperthyroidism. While it is less commonly associated with delayed puberty or obstructive sleep apnea, the metabolic disturbances might indirectly contribute to a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can cause lymphadenopathy, alopecia, and potentially affect puberty timing due to overall health impact. Given its systemic nature, it could indirectly contribute to other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system. It can directly cause lymphadenopathy. Some treatments or the disease itself could potentially contribute indirectly to delayed puberty, alopecia, and obstructive sleep apnea due to general health deterioration.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. It can cause delayed puberty and alopecia due to hormone imbalance. Obstructive sleep apnea is also more common in individuals with PCOS, often related to associated obesity.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer originating from lymphocytes. One of its classic symptoms is lymphadenopathy. The treatments, as well as the disease itself, can occasionally lead to secondary symptoms like alopecia or possibly impact puberty.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing. It can cause delayed puberty and lymphadenopathy. Alopecia and obstructive sleep apnea have been observed in some cases but are less directly associated.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia — a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause alopecia and, in severe cases, might contribute to delayed puberty. Not directly associated with lymphadenopathy, hyperactivity, or obstructive sleep apnea, but can exacerbate fatigue, potentially influencing these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
diagnoses.description: A virus that can lead to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. It can cause lymphadenopathy and, through its complex impacts on health, could indirectly contribute to delayed puberty, alopecia, hyperactivity, and obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can cause delayed puberty and contribute indirectly to symptoms like alopecia and obstructive sleep apnea. The association with hyperactivity is less direct, but chronic illness can affect overall wellbeing.

diagnoses: Primary Ovarian Insufficiency (a cause of delayed puberty)
Post-nasal drip syndrome (Upper airway cough syndrome)
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., vitamin B12, folate deficiency)
Neurological conditions (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease)
Rhinitis Medicamentosa (due to nasal congestion medication overuse)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (in context of multisystem involvement)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with lupus nephritis
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Allergic Reactions (e.g., to food or medication)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can sometimes present with numbness and weakness as aura symptoms before the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: Sudden numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, severe headache with no known cause can be signs of a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Characterized by symptoms like numbness, weakness, and problems with coordination and balance. Headaches are also reported by some people.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headaches
diagnoses.details: While primarily known for causing headache, prolonged tension can lead to sensations of numbness and perceived weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause symptoms similar to a stroke including numbness, weakness, and headache but usually resolves in minutes to hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause headaches, weakness, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Cervical Spondylosis
diagnoses.details: Degenerative changes in the cervical spine can press on nerves leading to numbness and weakness in the arms along with headaches.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: In its later stages, it can affect the nervous system causing headaches, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.details: This immune system disorder strikes quickly and can cause severe weakness and numbness shortly after symptoms begin.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: High blood sugar levels can lead to nerve damage, causing numbness and weakness in the extremities along with other symptoms.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Hepatitis B and C related arthropathies

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including rashes (potentially psoriaform), lymphopenia, renal involvement (proteinuria), and joint inflammation (synovitis). CNS lupus can manifest as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by psoriasis and joint inflammation (synovitis). Some patients may develop proteinuria due to renal involvement and delirium as a severe systemic response, although lymphopenia is less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primary manifestations include synovitis and joint deformities, systemic involvement can lead to skin manifestations, renal involvement (proteinuria), and, in severe cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory condition affects skin and muscles, causing rash (which can sometimes be psoriasiform) and muscle weakness. It can also lead to systemic manifestations including proteinuria and, rarely, delirium. Lymphopenia may occur due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the exocrine glands but can have systemic manifestations including lymphopenia and renal involvement. Psoriaform rashes and synovitis might be observed in more severe cases.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV can present with a wide variety of symptoms depending on the stage of the disease. Psoriaform rashes, lymphopenia due to the virus’ effect on the immune system, and renal involvement (proteinuria) are common. Patients can also develop arthritis and, in late stages, CNS involvement might cause delirium.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Manifests with skin changes that can sometimes mimic psoriasis, joint inflammation (synovitis), renal involvement, and in severe cases, can lead to central nervous system involvement causing delirium. Lymphopenia could occur in the context of systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD shares features with lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including skin rashes, joint inflammation, renal involvement, and could potentially lead to delirium. Lymphopenia is also a possible manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: In its late stages, Lyme disease can cause arthritis (typically knee synovitis), neurological symptoms including delirium, and has been associated with a variety of rashes, though typically not psoriasiform. Proteinuria is less common but can occur with Lyme nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that destroy blood vessels by inflammation. It can present with skin manifestations that may resemble psoriasis, renal involvement (proteinuria), joint pain or synovitis, and, in severe cases, central nervous system involvement leading to delirium. Lymphopenia can occur secondary to the systemic inflammation.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
